senses.ex: She embarked on a new career.

Tips.title: Initiating Action
Tips.description: Used when someone decides to take the first step in a series or process.
Tips.example: After years of planning, he's finally ready to embark on his PhD.

Tips.title: Personal Journeys
Tips.description: Often used metaphorically to refer to the start of personal endeavors or life changes.
Tips.example: She's about to embark on motherhood.

Tips.title: Long-term Commitment
Tips.description: Suggests a commitment to a long and perhaps challenging process.
Tips.example: They're ready to embark on a three-year research project.

senses.de: To get on a boat or a ship
senses.ex: Passengers are requested to embark immediately.

Tips.title: Physical Movement
Tips.description: Literally means to enter a vehicle, typically large transport like ships or large boats.
Tips.example: Tourists will embark the cruise ship at dawn.

Tips.title: Travel Context
Tips.description: Usually associated with the beginning of a trip or voyage.
Tips.example: Before we can embark, we must attend the safety briefing.

senses.de: To put or invest money in a business
senses.ex: He embarked all his savings in the new business.

Tips.title: Investment Focus
Tips.description: Refers to the act of putting resources, like money or effort, into something.
Tips.example: They decided to embark substantial funds into the new startup.

Tips.title: Financial Risk
Tips.description: Implies readiness to take a financial risk or invest with the expectation of a return.
Tips.example: Investors embark their capital in stocks for higher returns.

Begin.wordDefinition:
Begin usually means to start or commence something, while embark typically means to start a journey or a new project.

For example, you might begin writing a paper, but you would embark on a road trip. Begin is used more broadly and can refer to starting anything, while embark is usually used in the context of a specific endeavor, such as a new adventure or undertaking.

Commence.wordDefinition:
Commence means to begin or start something.

Commence describes the start of an event or activity, while embark describes the start of a journey or project.

Initiate.wordDefinition:
Embark and initiate both mean to begin or start something, but they are used in different contexts.

Initiate is used when beginning a process or introducing something new. For example, "The CEO initiated a company-wide policy to reduce plastic waste.".

Embark is used when starting something new and exciting, while initiate is used when starting a process or introducing something new.

Launch.wordDefinition:
Both embark and launch refer to starting or beginning something.

Launch is typically used in the context of introducing a new product, service, or event to the public. For example, you would say "We are launching a new smartphone next month" or "The company is launching a charity fundraiser this weekend.".

Embark describes starting a journey or project, while launch describes introducing something new to the public.

Start.wordDefinition:
Both words, embark and start, indicate the beginning of something.

However, embark usually implies a more significant undertaking or journey, such as embarking on a new career, whereas start can refer to any new beginning, big or small, such as starting a new hobby.

Embark is used when someone starts a big or important task, while start can be used in any scenario.

videos.Title: The hidden power of...

quotes.Text: Once you do embark upon the separation or divorce process, it is very important to remember three key things: Be kind, be reasonable, be brief. Remember that this person will no longer be your spouse, but he or she will continue to be your co-parent, family member, and perhaps business partner in certain assets or entities.
quotes.Title: American Lawyer
quotes.Name: Laura Wasser

quotes.Text: If a school makes an effort to provide kids the right foods and help them to be more active, this benefits the student and the family's health. If you embark on a program to improve your health with a church or community group, you are more likely to stick with it over time.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Tom Rath

quotes.Text: In the writing of poetry we never know anything for sure. We will never know if we have 'trained' or 'practised' enough. We will never be able to say that we have reached grade eight, or that we have left the grades behind and are now embarked on an advanced training.
quotes.Title: British Poet
quotes.Name: James Fenton

quotes.Text: The spiritual quest is not some added benefit to our life, something you embark on if you have the time and inclination. We are spiritual beings on an earthly journey. Our spirituality makes up our beingness.
quotes.Title: American Philosopher
quotes.Name: John Bradshaw

quotes.Text: Self-publishing is fine. But in a world of self-publishing, where everything is about what you get on the back end, there's a serious disincentive from embarking on really important, vital projects.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Franklin Foer

quotes.Text: I can't think of a story that doesn't have something terrible in it. Otherwise, it's dull. So when I embarked into the world of picture books, my first thought was to do something about the dark.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Daniel Handler

quotes.Text: Keep only those things that speak to your heart. Then take the plunge and discard all the rest. By doing this, you can reset your life and embark on a new lifestyle.
quotes.Title: Japanese Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Marie Kondo

quotes.Text: The best of life is to embark on an adventure with a woman interested in having an adventure with you.
quotes.Title: American Designer
quotes.Name: Oleg Cassini

quotes.Text: If you're embarking around the world in a hot-air balloon, don't forget the toilet paper.
quotes.Title: British Businessman
quotes.Name: Richard Branson

quotes.Text: I embarked on my life - I didn't do anything. I don't have an explanation.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Don DeLillo
